Below is information that you will need when configuring an Identity Provider. You may not need all of this information for your use-case. Different Identity Providers require different settings for their SimpleSAML set-up. The login URL is the URL that will be used by anonymous users to start the SAML authentication process. The debug URL can be used while setting up the Identity Provider, it starts the authentication process but redirects to a debug screen to show the data that is sent by the Identity Provider, it does not log you into the Open Social site.

Controls what Open Social does with profile information that is present in Open Social but not in a SAML request. A setting other than never may cause manually filled in profile information in Open Social to be lost. However, a value of never will cause profile information removed in the Identity Provider to remain in Open Social.

Example: eduPersonPrincipalName or displayName
The attribute to be used as username.
The value of this attribute must be unique within Open Social and may be displayed to users depending on platform settings.
Several special characters are allowed in values of this attribute, including space, period (.), hyphen (-), apostrophe ('), and underscore (_).
If the attribute is multivalued, the first value will be used.

Example: eduPersonPrincipalName or eduPersonTargetedID
Used to connect a user in Open Social to a user in the identity provider.
The value of this attribute must be unique and remain constant.
If the attribute is multivalued, the first value will be used.

Example: mail
The attribute to be used as e-mail. This will be used to send notifications to the user.
The value of this attribute must be unique in Open Social and be a valid e-mail.
If the attribute is multivalued, the first value will be used.

For each role a semicolon separated list of conditions. A role is assigned if a least one condition matches. Each condition consists of a a SimpleSAML attribute name, an operation and a value to match. e.g. attribute_name,operation,value;attribute_name2,operation,value... etc

Each operation may be either "@", "@=" or "~=".
  • "=" requires the value exactly matches the attribute;
  • "@=" requires the portion after a "@" in the attribute to match the value;
  • "~=" allows the value to match any part of any element in the attribute array.
For instance setting Content manager to affiliation,=,employee;affiliation,=,external-support would ensure any user who has an affiliation attribute with a value of "employee" or "external-support" would receive the Content manager role.

On this screen you are only able to configure rules for roles that you are allowed to assign manually.

The use of a metadata URL is recommended. Open Social will fetch the metadata from the provided URL every 24 hours. If no metadata URL is available then the metadata should be uploaded as file. Metadata from the provided URL will take precedence over manually uploaded metadata.

This section allows you to control how attributes sent by the ADFS server correspond to Open Social.
Unlimited

Upon federated login, check if a local, pre-existing Drupal user is present that can be linked to the SAML authname (by default Drupal username is checked). If so, enable SAML authentication for this existing user.
WARNING: make sure there is an actual link between the SAML authname and pre-existing Drupal usernames, otherwise the Drupal user could be taken over by someone else authenticating with a SAML authname that happens to be the same.
NOTE: When enabled, the pre-existing user can be modified (e.g. get other username, email address, roles, ... based on SAML attributes).

When checked, the email address stored in Open Social will be updated by the value sent by the identity provider on every login.

When checked, the profile information stored in Open Social will be updated wtth the values sent by the identity provider on every login. When unchecked this synchronisation only happens during registration.
When checked, the username stored in Open Social will be updated by the value sent by the identity provider on every login.
